H0.text: Animalia is the kingdom most likely to include the unusual plant‑like organism that the student found while hiking in Granville State Forest, which lacks chlorophyll and whose cells have cell walls but no chloroplasts.

H1.text: Eubacteria are the kingdom most likely to include the unusual plant‑like organism the student found in Granville State Forest, whose cells have cell walls and no chloroplasts.

H2.text: Fungi are the Kingdom that includes an unusual plant‑like organism lacking chlorophyll, with many cells that have cell walls but no chloroplasts, as observed by a student hiking through Granville State Forest who examined a sample under a microscope.

H3.text: Protista is the Kingdom that is most likely to include the plant‑like organism the student found while hiking in Granville State Forest, which lacks chlorophyll, has many cells with cell walls, and has no chloroplasts.

A4.text: Fungi are unusual among the eukaryotes in having a cell wall that, in addition to glucans (e.g., β-1,3-glucan) and other typical components, also contains the biopolymer chitin. Fungi lack chloroplasts and are heterotrophic organisms.

A5.text: The fungi are now considered a separate kingdom, distinct from both plants and animals, from which they appear to have diverged around one billion years ago (around the start of the Neoproterozoic Era).
